body:
I added Apache NiFi to the Netty adopters page:

https://github.com/netty/netty/wiki/Adopters
@JackHintonSmartDCSIT Looks like your last commit created some conflicts.

We should not be changing behavior with this change.  The intent to avoid calling toString as we are so that we can benefit from it being invoked when needed by the logger depending on levels is good.  But changing behavior is not.

If I follow correctly many of these changes would mean instead of giving direct exception messages in cases where it can be useful we'd instead follow the log output with a big stack trace.  In my experience this results in far less useful log output.

I'm not saying we can't improve things but I am saying a blanket removal of 'toString' calls isn't the answer when it comes to error handling vs logging

I'd be curious to hear what @exceptionfactory has in mind.

But i will say from a user point of view (which was the point of the 'due to - message') mechanism we do want to surface/provide detailed log information and often times these toString outputs for exceptions are more valuable to a user than the exception stack trace.  We generally provided both but notably the message was on the same line as the main log output.  Stacktraces are in a series of lines that follow.  

We need to ensure what we do here is rooted in what gives value to the user as that is more important than the performance savings of 'toString' being invoked or not.

If you can show a before/after that would be helpful.  But please let's make sure a change that is rooted in being about avoiding calls isn't also changing behavior without us considering what that change means for the user.

Thanks

> @JackHintonSmartDCSIT Looks like your last commit created some conflicts.

Huh I rebased against main. I guess, incorrectly..

EDIT:
Ah, that looks like it worked.

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

Had a minor heart attack there - turns out that rebase went really badly wrong and I managed to revert everything by 2 weeks. A minor scramble through this repo later, I've gotten it back to where it was prior to the 'rebase' I attempted.

@JackHintonSmartDCSIT I pushed one comment to reformat all of the files. You may have addressed it in an earlier commit that was lost in the rebase, but I noticed almost all the files had a single extra space indenting each line.

Aside from that, the code looks good and runtime testing with various files from WireShark [SampleCaptures](https://wiki.wireshark.org/SampleCaptures) worked well.

Do you have any further feedback @dan-s1?

Otherwise, I think this should be ready to go pending successful builds!
Ah fair enough, good spot!

@exceptionfactory I am good. I think everything looks great!
@JackHintonSmartDCSIT Thank you so much for working this ticket so diligently! You have done a great job to address all issues. This feature will certainly add great value.
@dan-s1 No worries! Thank you both for helping to get it where it is!
Reviewing...

> @sullis, If you are not familiar with those details, I could take a look at making the appropriate adjustments and pushing a change to this branch. This is certainly one of those changes that requires runtime testing and careful evaluation, since unit tests do not have the same class loader structure as runtime deployments.

Please go ahead and make any adjustments that you need.  Feel free to push your updates to this PR.

Thanks for the reply @gforeman02, if you willing to rework the PR along the lines of using dynamic properties with wildcards as a way to support dynamic metadata keys, that sounds like a good way forward, without introducing new properties.
Will review...

> @exceptionfactory From my admittedly limited reading the impression I had is that these native implementations become substantially more efficient at high rates/high scale/many concurrent connections/etc.. I suspect we'd not see it in routine testing but rather in deliberately pushing the agenda.
> 
> With that in mind I am more inclined to suggest this only be activated via a profile allowing evaluation over time but avoiding inclusion in the normal case for now.
> 
> Just my two cents. I'm cool with a different approach too.

Thanks for the feedback @joewitt. I agree from reading some reference that the performance benefits should be more noticeable around large numbers of connections, so that's just where I would like to see a bit more comparison between Java 21 NIO and the native transports. With JDK improvements, perhaps the differences are not as noticeable, or only noticeable in certain circumstances. That's where having more recent and substantive examples would be helpful.

I'm not favor of a profile-based approach, because that would make the code more complicated, not being able to compile as it stands, if the libraries were not included. This could certainly be implemented using reflection, but as a non-default profile, I expect it would be minimally used.

To be clear, I think this could still be valuable, I would just like to see some type of scenario in NiFi, or benchmarks from other systems on Java 21, that illustrate the benefits.
Thanks for the fix, merging
@exceptionfactory Alright. I'll open a PR for this functionality on support/nifi-1.x and then start refactoring this PR to use AWS 2.X APIs. Does that work for you?

> @exceptionfactory Alright. I'll open a PR for this functionality on support/nifi-1.x and then start refactoring this PR to use AWS 2.X APIs. Does that work for you?

I recommend refactoring first, as the AWS SDK 2 libraries are also available on the support branch. Working through the changes on the main branch first should limit the amount of work necessary to consider back-porting.
Ok. Will do. I will probably have to massively expand the scope of this PR but it is what it is...

Thanks for closer review @exceptionfactory,

The ConsumeKafka_2_6 processor maintains its original behavior even with flowfile support. It can collect Kafka messages regardless of its connection status and without needing stimulation from a flowfile. The key difference is its new capability to support flowfile processing, allowing for dynamic topic changes. I think this change does not increase complexity significantly; it simply adds a new feature while preserving the original behavior.

@andrealves23 First thank you for contributing.  I can appreciate the intent.  That said I do agree with the response of @exceptionfactory.

A couple things at play.  First is related to the maintainability of the Kafka components.  We should be getting rid of the Kafka 2.x components soon in favor of Kafka 3.7/latest or even 4.0 as it will be out very soon.  There is a long standing active effort to refactor the Kafka processors underway as well.  And of course this is just consume kafka and we also have record oriented processors as well.  We can't have behavior deviating too far.

Secondarily there is then the question of this change relative to the purpose of the processor.  That processor is written as a source component and designed as such.  Switching to allow it to accept flowfiles as input which are effectively signals to change which topic(s) it pays attention to is likely not producing enough of a clear user experience improvement.

As I read this it means the input flowfiles act as signals/switches to change which topic is being monitored.  In your intent/flow how will that really work in terms of 'what' creates the input flowfiles and at what rate will new flowfiles arrive?  What happens if a new flowfile comes in and there is still more to read on the topic(s) in question/etc.? 

This is too complex as-is for a user and changes an otherwise extremely critical/common use component.

To be clear i'm not rejecting the idea.  You may well be on to something.  I suggest it is offered with a more detailed writeup of the 'why' and how it would work in practice/is intended to work.  Then a component that is specific to this DynamicConsumeKafka* pattern.  This way we can all offer thoughts on the first part before having to react to the code.

The writeup on the JIRA is a good start but what it lacks is a discussion/description around 'what and how' signaling of topic changes would occur.  We need to understand more of that intent/picture.
+1 LGTM, had to change Set.of() for backport but merging to support/nifi-1.x and main. Thanks for the fix!

@exceptionfactory I looked at the code (and ultimately the rest service endpoints) calling clone() in these `Entity` classes and didn't see any reason why they shouldn't be taking care of `id` as well.

Nice catch :)
+1 LGTM, thanks for the fix! Merging to support/nifi-1.x and main
Looks like there are some merge and/or rebase issues here, might be worth a new PR applying the desired commits to a feature branch based off the latest main branch.

> Looks like there are some merge and/or rebase issues here, might be worth a new PR applying the desired commits to a feature branch based off the latest main branch.

I have created new PR please have a look

@exceptionfactory I did some experimentation with this today, and there is going to be a lot of refactoring work in both the abstract processors module and the aws processors module to get the S3 stuff migrated. I'd rather add these with the V1 API since they're thin wrappers over that API and then do a bigger ticket afterward to try to get everything on the V2 API.

I see your point, but I'd rather get this functionality in now so it's available because we have some use cases that really need it. I don't think it'll add much to that refactoring task.
Closing this in favor of the new PR, thanks!
@gforeman02 Heads up: you have merge conflicts with `main` that need to be resolved on your branch.
Merged into 1.x
Will review...

Thanks for the follow up @MikeThomsen.

Incorporating new Processors and refactoring in the same pull request for S3 doesn't sound ideal, and I agree that the scope of these Processors is fairly narrow in terms of S3 API changes. With that in mind, considering these Processors as they stand seems like a reasonable way forward.

To that end, there are a few things I recommend evaluating. The Copy Processor seems straightforward, and I can take a closer look at potential changes there. I would note that new properties should just use a human-readable `name()` instead of a different `displayName()` going forward.

On the Exists Processor, I think it would be better to have it function as a `GetS3ObjectMetadata` Processor. The `doesObjectExist()` method requests the metadata, but ignores the response. I think having the metadata would present other potential uses beyond just whether the object exists, while still supporting that particular use case.
strong +1 on David's comments regarding GetS3ObjectMetadata instead of an exists call.

@gforeman02 Given the current conflicts and the different direction, I'm closing this pull request for now. Feel free to reopen when you are ready with a different approach, or open a new PR if you prefer. Thanks!
@exceptionfactory Sure!

Thanks for the additional perspective @joewitt.

@andrealves23 new Kafka Processors and Controller Services are now part of the main branch following the merge of #8463.

As Joe suggested, I recommend writing up a more detailed use case of how this dynamic topic polling would work in the associated Jira issue. Although the code changes may be small, the implications for flow design are very significant. If you can describe the general concept there, and what should drive selecting a topic to poll, that would be very helpful.

With the new `KafkaConnectionService` API, there is now an abstraction around producing or consuming Kafka records, avoiding tight coupling between NiFi Processors and the Kafka client library version. This new Controller Service API also provides a new way to introduce different Kafka-based Processors.

With that background, I am closing this current pull request, but feel free to continue the discussion on the Jira after evaluating the options based on the new components.

Hello @exceptionfactory @markap14,
It would be great to follow up on this topic. The solution would affect the PropertyDependency and Custom relationship values as well. This information is missing from doc generation as well. I found a related JIRA already: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13432  
Based on what @briansolo1985 said, the current approach to how NiFi interact with the Python libraries and AST has a limitation. I wonder if you had a chance to look into this in more detail or have an alternative solution/suggestion.

Thank you very much @exceptionfactory for looking at this (as well as [8983](https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/8983))
I very much appreciate it.

@dan-s1 Thanks for following up. I agree with you that `poi-utils` is not really necessary in retrospect, so if you would fold that back in to the `nifi-poi-services` module, that would be a useful separate Jira and PR.

With that change in place, then a separate new PR for potential backporting would be in order.

@exceptionfactory One more issue. Now that `SplitProcessor` ended up `nifi-poi-services`, I noticed the two packages are somewhat awkward

- `org.apache.nifi.excel`
- `org.apache.nifi.processors.excel`

Should the first one perhaps be renamed to  `org.apache.nifi.services.excel` or something like that to indicate they are controller services? I then could place the `ProtectionType` under a new package `org.apache.nifi.excel.utils`. As it stands currently, `ProtectionType` is under package name `org.apache.nifi.excel`so I would be moving it back to the controller services package with the new ticket I created [NIFI-13442](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/NIFI-13442).

I would not move the `ExcelReader` since that would break existing flow definitions.

I would either leave `ProtectionType` under `org.apache.nifi.excel`, or just move it to `org.apache.nifi.excel.property`.

I'll take a look into that @joewitt @exceptionfactory but it might be right to have 3 processors instead. I recall something about how doesObjectExists uses a HEAD which is faster for S3 than trying to fetch the metadata when your only goal is to ask whether the object exists. I'll look into it and adjust accordingly.

> I'll take a look into that @joewitt @exceptionfactory but it might be right to have 3 processors instead. I recall something about how doesObjectExists uses a HEAD which is faster for S3 than trying to fetch the metadata when your only goal is to ask whether the object exists. I'll look into it and adjust accordingly.

@MikeThomsen The `doesObjectExist()` method calls `getObjectMetadata()`, so there should be no difference in performance. That's the reason I suggested going that direction, thus I would not recommend a separate processor for checking object existence.

@sullis I went through some additional runtime testing on Ubuntu Linux to evaluate any notable differences. Based on some general reading, it seems like the Netty epoll implementation on Linux can be helpful in certain scenarios with large numbers of short-lived connections, but not necessarily with long-lived connections. I also noted that the OpenJDK NIO implementation uses epoll, but the triggering mechanism is different.

With this background, I'm not discounting the value of Netty native transports in certain scenarios, but it also seems like the value is only apparent under certain conditions.

I appreciate the background work on this, but I think it would be better to avoid a general change and instead consider particular components and use cases where it could provide value. As mentioned previously, although the libraries are fairly small, there should be a compelling reason to begin incorporating them in standard builds.

If you are interested in evaluating some particular Processors or use cases that highlight the value of Netty native libraries, that would be beneficial. Without that though, I'm not in favor of moving forward right now.

Thanks for pinging @exceptionfactory. Truthfully I would prefer not implementing anything until we provide a full solution. But it's not a particularly strong preference. I wouldn't necessarily oppose the addition as proposed here.
Let's close this for now. I might revisit this when Netty 4.2 becomes available. (Version 4.2 will include the io_uring transport)
Thanks @sullis, that sounds good, closing for now.

Hey @pgyori :wave: Just out of curiosity - have you thought about offering a version of the `FlowFileSourceProxy` for processors that are **not** safe for concurrent execution?

Currently there is no way of setting annotations such as `@TriggerSerially `from the Python side - most regular processors are fine with 'Concurrent Tasks' > 1 but I have several source processors I would like to develop where running multiple concurrent tasks would be rather ... problematic :innocent:

I share the view that this is a wise move as it is not otherwise clear this is specifically intended for K8S based deployment scenarios.  I think we should ensure this ends up in the migration guidance but I think this is far more intentional about its purpose.
Thanks for the additional perspective @joewitt. I'm fine with renaming the class, we can just note the change in a migration guide step.

@krisztina-zsihovszki Is there not a good place to put this capability within existing components already?  This feels like a uniquely specific processor.  That said I recognize the slack api is pretty unique

changeset looks great.  Doing a full local build and will run a quick test on docker based deploy

but this combined with the import of these components into the nifi-python-extensions and we're in good shape!
Merged in https://github.com/apache/nifi/commit/6e69b7009c669b0aaf554b5cb5e17b2fdc5decd6

I just noticed that `ListSFTP` unlike `ListFile` does not populate both `path` and `absolute.path` but only `path` instead.

I'll adjust the PR accordingly.

> Thanks for the additional perspective @joewitt. I'm fine with renaming the class, we can just note the change in a migration guide step.

Thanks, @exceptionfactory.  Are there any additional changes needed on this?
Thanks for the review, I've applied the requested changes

> Hey @pgyori 👋 Just out of curiosity - have you thought about offering a version of the `FlowFileSourceProxy` for processors that are **not** safe for concurrent execution?
> 
> Currently there is no way of setting annotations such as `@TriggerSerially `from the Python side - most regular processors are fine with 'Concurrent Tasks' > 1 but I have several source processors I would like to develop where running multiple concurrent tasks would be rather ... problematic 😇

Thanks for raising this question @henrikjohansen. This is probably worth considering in a discussion in Jira, where it would be helpful to outline the type of Processor to be developed. It is worth noting that a large number of the `List` Processors in Java have the `TriggerSerially` annotation, so it might even make sense to make that the standard behavior. However, I think this can be considered as a follow-on effort, as the implications may be a bit different given the relationship between Java Threads and Python processes.

> Hey @pgyori 👋 Just out of curiosity - have you thought about offering a version of the `FlowFileSourceProxy` for processors that are **not** safe for concurrent execution?
> 
> Currently there is no way of setting annotations such as `@TriggerSerially `from the Python side - most regular processors are fine with 'Concurrent Tasks' > 1 but I have several source processors I would like to develop where running multiple concurrent tasks would be rather ... problematic 😇

Hi @henrikjohansen ,
That is a very interesting - and challenging - problem. Thank you for asking that! I agree with @exceptionfactory , let's open a separate Jira ticket for that and discuss it further.

Thank you @lordgamez , @henrikjohansen , @exceptionfactory ! 
I appreciate the feedback. I pushed a commit addressing the review comments.
Thanks @pgyori! The changes look good, so I plan to merge after verifying the builds.

PR adjusted accordingly. 
The implementation is inspired by both that of `DeleteFile` and `PutSFTP`.

I would appreciate a review. 🙂
responded in the JIRA.  Trying to understand the actual use case before commenting on the implementation.  This implementation might be idea.  Just can't tell yet.
Thanks for applying the recommended changes. LGTM +1. Will proceed with the merge

I understand your perspectives, @exceptionfactory  and @joewitt. 

Therefore, as requested, I added more details to the ticket description to explain why it is essential for Apache NiFi to support dynamic Kafka topic management.

I haven't investigated the new Kafka processor code yet, but the idea is to discuss via the Jira ticket whether this feature can genuinely help and improve the user experience. If it is something we decide to move forward with, I will review the new code and determine the best way to add this feature to NiFi.
This was actually fixed elsewhere, in #5495.
I would love to hear your thoughts on this @pvillard31, as you were the one to introduce `mapOf` some months ago.

Thank you for the fast feedback @joewitt.

It makes sense to avoid outdated language features targeting the 2.x branch. I'll adjust the PR accordingly. 
If that's what we strive for, which seems desirable, we might need to watch out for that more on PR reviews though.

However I'm wondering, what are the reasons why you're against backports for the 1.x line while 2.x isn't stable yet?

1. use latest language features/better code - thanks.
2. Watch on PRs. - I assure you there are several of us that are.  But there are a lot of contributors and it is massive codebase.  We miss stuff.
3. I am not against it.  I simply have been for quite some time not recommending it. As long as people keep adding features and improvements to 1.x more than they focus on getting 2.0 done then it gets harder and harder to get 2.x done.  What you focus on and wish to happen will happen.  What you wait for....may not.  Bottom line I am in the hearts and minds business.  I recommend and encourage folks focus on the go forward solution.  The 1.x line is great but it is already experiencing atrophy.  I strongly believe our best way to help/support/grow the community is to look forward.  This is just my view - you'll get an impressive amount of opinions on such a topic.

Thank you for addressing my questions @joewitt. I always appreciate getting to know the perspective and especially reasoning of others on topics. 

I adjusted the PR accordingly. It mostly affected the tests though. 

I would appreciate a review (not necessarily by you, of course).

Thanks @exceptionfactory that's a great catch. Calling into an extension point when unnecessary is definitely worth addressing. Looks like we've made similar changes in the past but didn't go far enough. Definitely a +1 on this change. Will wait for the Github Actions to complete and assuming that they are all clear, I'll merge to main. Thanks for the improvement!

- some stuff around the MaxLengthInputStream
- the afterProperties method question

Regarding the comment about needing to refresh the UI... Currently the UI retrieves the lists of processor and controller service types one time when the canvas is loaded. We can file something to try and improve it, but I consider it a separate effort since it already impacts stuff like dropping a NAR into ./extenions, or a NAR being pulled from a NarProvider and download into ./extensions.

Is this because the libraries are vulnerable and/or not up to date?

> Is this because the libraries are vulnerable and/or not up to date?

The `subethasmtp` library has gone through several iterations of forking, and the [most recent fork](https://github.com/davidmoten/subethasmtp) has had some helpful recent updates.

The Netty framework has some SMTP codec classes that could provide a better foundation, but I think the fundamental question relates to the use of ListenSMTP itself. The component description notes that it does not perform any email validation, which effectively requires an external SMTP server for runtime use. Running ListenSMTP with direct network exposure is very dangerous, so its current use cases are limited.
Merged in https://github.com/apache/nifi/commit/89741f6160a0f7e8a8289b51bd71259c4f79d80d
ok this next commit i think got em all
thanks done
